tooltip: If you so choose, you no longer feel the short-term negative effects from over-indulging in alcohol, drugs or other vices.

name: Debauchery
description: You may perform one additional Short Rest between each Long Rest, as long as you indulge in some kind of worldy pleasure while doing so.
tooltip: You perform an additional Short Rest, indulging in some kind of worldy pleasure while doing so.

name: Entitlement
description: You are owed certain things in life, and you deserve to get them. Add a die to your dice pool when attempting a task related to obtaining something you believe you are owed.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool when attempting a task related to obtaining something you believe you are owed.

name: Piercing Gaze
description: With a look, you render a target within short range silent for 1d6 rounds.
tooltip: With a look, you render a target within short range silent for 1d6 rounds.

name: Absolute Authority
description: All non-player characters who can understand automatically follow your commands without the need for a roll. A command is a simple task that does not harm the indiviual, though you can have they attack allies. Can only do once between each Rest.
tooltip: You command all non-player characters who can understand to automatically follow your commands without the need for a roll.

name: Offputting
description: Something about you invokes visible disgust in those around you. Whether a physical deformity, an obscene tattoo, your sense of style or just the way you carry yourself, people can't help but find you unbearable to look at or be around. As a result, remove one die from your dice pool whenever you have a positive social interaction with other characters.
tooltip: Something about you invokes visible disgust in those around you. Remove a die from your dice pool on positive social interactions.

name: Clear the Room
description: Using your particular brand of repugnance, you cause all targets within immediate range to retreat to short distance or further away from you. You do not have control over their direction.
tooltip: You cause all targets within immediate range to retreat to short distance or further away from you.

name: Let the Hate Flow
description: You've had enough. Use the built up hatred directed at you to add one die to your dice roll on any Attack roll.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice roll on any Attack roll.

name: Means & Oppurtunity
description: Once per session, you can automatically succeed on any task of your choosing, as long as you're skilled in that task.
tooltip: You automatically succeed on a task of your choosing, as long as you're skilled in that task.

name: White Noise
description: You are immune to attempts to compromise your mind, including control, daze, confuse and mind reading.
tooltip: You are immune to attempts to compromise your mind, including control, daze, confuse and mind reading.

name: Learn Something New Everyday
description:
You've always been a quick learner, fueled by your love of education and your immeasurable curiosity. You read textbooks, listen to lectures or recall past lessons every night when going to sleep. You awake refreshed, ready to take on the day with your new knowledge.

Your Long Rest as normal in terms of Healing and ability reset, but also adds two dice to your dice pool when tackling tasks related to a specific knowledge Skill you chose the night before through the Apply Newfound Knowledge ability. For example, if you read a textbook on the properties of dihydrogen monoxide the night before, you will have an easier time with chemistry related tasks until your next Long Rest. You can choose the same knowledge Skill multiple times in a row if you wish.
tooltip: Whenever you Long Rest, select a knowledge Skill to apply to your Apply Newfound Knowledge ability.

name: <hide>
description: Make a note of the knowledge Skill you selected during your last Long Rest for the Apply Newfound Knowledge ability. Select a knowledge Skill to apply to this ability at start the game.

name: Apply Newfound Knowledge
description: Because of your late-night cram session, add two dice to your dice pool when tackling a task related to whatever knowledge Skill you studied during your last Long Rest.
tooltip: Add two dice to your dice pool when tackling a task related to whatever knowledge Skill you studied during your last Long Rest.

name: Receptive Soul
description:
You are unbiased and without prejudice, able to consider all points of view and re-evaluate your beliefs accordingly. Throughout your journey, you will encounter new ideas. If these new ideas have a chance to change your outlook on life, you can change an aspect of yourself as a way to show acceptance of these new alternative mindsets. It can be something as minor as changing your favourite drink, to something as major as changing your Type or Focus. Regardless, you're always down to trying to new things.

Once per session, you can change one aspect about yourself based on your interactions with the world and other characters. A minor change to your personality or preferences awards 1 XP. A major change to your Type or Focus awards 4 XP, but you must provide a reason for the drastic change. Physical changes do not trigger this XP bonus unless the change is tied to a change in ideals. For example, a character once opposed to cybernetics getting cyberware.
tooltip: You change a minor aspect of yourself for 1 XP, or your Type or Focus for 4 XP. Only usable once per session.

name: Yes Ma'am, Thank You Ma'am
description: If someone asks you for Help, you cannot refuse. If you Help someone in this way and you get a critical success, the target automatically succeeds on their roll. However, if you fail, you alone receive any negative consequences, including those from an Intrusion.
tooltip: You cannot refuse if someone asks you for Help. A critical success on your Help roll causes the target to automatically succeed , but you receive all negative consequences if you fail.

name: Subservience
description:
Unlike other player characters, you are completely unable to take Actions out of your own will. You can only act when provided explicit orders by another character. This other character does not have to be a player character, but they must provide instructions explicitly. They do not need to direct your Actions every round and can provide general directions such as, "follow me and do as I do" or "storm that building and kill everyone inside". You still have autonomous control over your biological needs; this rule only applies to Actions that have significant consequences. It is up to you how granular and specific orders need to be, but you cannot take new Actions on your own.

Additionally, you receive a small amount of psychological Harm every turn you spend without someone's orders to carry out, either because none were given or because you're unsure what do next.

As an example, if your party is trying to rob a bank, you may be provided with the task of Guarding the door. If so, you must Guard the door until told otherwise. However, if you are left alone and a hostage asks you to free them, and you were not told NOT to listen to the hostages, you would have to free them.
tooltip: You are unable to take Actions out of your own will and must follow orders from another character. You take Harm when not following orders.

name: Await Orders
description: You automatically succeed at helping another character in a skill you're trained in, as long as the character has previously told you what to do.
tooltip: You automatically succeed at Helping another character in a Skill you're trained in, as long as you were told what to do.

name: Like-minded Soul
description: To some people, there's nothing better than allowing someone to make all the decisions for you. You convince a like-minded ally to join you in your travels. Like you, they are unable to take any Actions of their own will, instead doing exactly as you are ordered by other characters. If you like your companion, a new one will join you within 1d6+3 days.
itemeffect: An NPC Companion who follows you around, doing exactly as you are ordered to do

name: Complete Subservience
description:
Unlike other player characters, you are completely unable to take Actions out of your own will. You can only act when provided explicit orders by another character. This other character does not have to be a player character, but they must provide instructions explicitly. They do not need to direct your Actions every round and can provide general directions such as, "follow me and do as I do" or "storm that building and kill everyone inside". You still have autonomous control over your biological needs; this rule only applies to Actions that have significant consequences. It is up to you how granular and specific orders need to be, but you cannot take new Actions on your own.

Additionally, you receive a small amount of psychological Harm every round you do not follow someone's orders, either because none were given, you took an Action without being ordered to do so or because you're unsure what do next.

You now heal Harm when you succeed at following instructions provided by another character. The effect only triggers when on a full or critical success.

As an example, if your party is trying to rob a bank, you may be provided with the task of Guarding the door. If so, you must Guard the door until told otherwise. However, if you are left alone and a hostage asks you to free them, and you were not told NOT to listen to the hostages, you would have to free them.
tooltip: You are unable to take Actions on your own and must follow orders from another character. You take Harm when not following orders, and Heal when following orders.

name: Intuit Intentions
description: Using your previous experience at following orders, you act out of your own will without taking Harm. Add two dice to your dice pool for whatever task you are undertaking.
tooltip: You act out of your own will without taking Harm, adding two dice to your dice pool for whatever task you are undertaking.

name: It Is What It Is
description: Bad things happens—that's just life. Good things happen too, and that, as well, is just life. You're not too bothered by either, really. You no longer feel the negative effects of mixed successes, but you also do not get any minor or major effects from critical successes. In other words, mixed successes and critical successes become full successes instead.
tooltip: You no longer feel the negative effects of mixed successes, but you also do not get any minor or major effects from critical successes.

name: It's All the Same to Me
description: Success or failure, it doesn't really matter. Once between each Long Rest you can change the outcome of any roll, including any made by allies, as long as they directly affect you in some way. This means you can switch a failed roll to a critical success, or a critical success to a fail, invoking an Intrusion in the process.
tooltip: Change the outcome of any roll that directly affects you in some way.

name: Calorie Intake
description: To keep up your tight bod, you need to consume twice as many calories as normal people. This means you go through rations and other food items twice as fast as other characters.
tooltip: You go through rations and other food items twice as fast as other characters.

name: Workout Plan
description: Everyday you don't workout is a day further from your goals. Everytime you Rest, you also take the time to sneak in a quick workout. Roll 1d2 whenever you're ready to Rest. If successful, you gain the benefits of Resting and get a sweet workout in. On a failed roll, you do not get the benefits of Resting and must wait until you can Rest again. This ability replaces both your Short Rest and your Long Rest.
tooltip: Roll 1d2 whenever you Rest. If successful, you gain the benefits of Resting. If you fail, you do not get the benefits of Resting.

name: Instructional Text
description: You start the game with an instructional text for whatever topic you are a novice in. You can reference this text whenever you need to tackle a task related to your chosen topic, adding a die to your dice pool for the roll.

name: Sometimes I'm Right
description: You might be no expert, but you're getting there. You know just enough to be dangerous, though sometimes you just have to fake it until you make it. When you so choose, roll 1d2 when tackling a task. On a successful roll, you succeed at the task through your skills or know-how, as well as a bit of guesswork. If you fail, you get an Intrusion. You cannot add die to this dice roll.
tooltip: Roll 1d2 when tackling any task. On a successful roll, you succeed. If you fail, get an Intrusion.

name: Omnimatrix
description: Every situation asks for something different. You must change your Focus every time you achieve a new Tier and everytime you start a new adventure, ideally something that would most closely match whatever challenge you're about to face.
tooltip: You must change your Focus every time you achieve a new Tier and everytime you start a new adventure.

name: New Day, New Me
description: Immediately after each Long Rest, you may roll to change your Focus without waiting for the next adventure or Tier. This roll can either use Logic, Feelings, Tech or Magic, depending on the Focus you are switching to.
tooltip: Roll Logic, Feelings, Magic or Tech to change your Focus without waiting for the next adventure or Tier.

name: Already Outstanding Collection
description:
You are a collector of things—very specific things. Some people may think these things don't have value. But you know better, and so does a select group of people you've come to know who share your passions. Geek, nerd, freak—these are all familiar insults to you, but you cannot be deterred. You see the monetary value in the objects you collect and, more importantly, the inherit value of owning them which always gives you warm, fuzzy feelings inside.

You start the game with three Expensive collector's items and one Very Expensive collector's item on your person.
itemname: Very Expensive Collector's Item (of your choice)

name: Dreams Do Come True
description:
Through a miracle of science or a Magic mishap, one of your collector's items that you choose comes to life and follows you around. If the object was already animate in some fashion beforehand, it now acts like a true companion, being able to speak and interact at will with the world around it. Discuss with the GM how the object will manifest its sentience, as the type of object will determine what it can or can't do. For example, cards or paintings could be represented instead by what's inside them, while simple constructs could remain as such, but have sentience all the same.

The newly animate collectible cannot take independent Actions or leave your immediate area. In truth, it’s more an extension of you than a separate being. Whenever the collectible is next to you, add a die to your dice pool. If you lose the collectible, another one of your collectibles will animate within 1d6+3 days.
itemname: Collectible Come to Life (of your choice)

name: Time to Give Back
description: After so much time consuming content related to your chosen aesthetic, you've decided to contribute back in some way. You are now trained in a crafting skill related to your chosen aesthetic.
itemname: Crafting Skill (related to your chosen aesthetic)

name: Brand Ambassador
description: With your legion of followers as a bargaining chip, you are able to use your sizeable influence to acquire the equivalent of a Very Expensive item from someone currently trying to sell it to you, without paying for it. Or, you can appeal to your followers to purchase one of your items without much effort on your part and at great profit.
tooltip: You acquire the equivalent of a Very Expensive item for free, or you sell one of your items to your followers at great profit.

name: Don't @ Me
description: When you really think about it, was it really your fault? Or is it just a disinformation campaign constructed to take you down? Once between each Rest, you can deflect an Intrusion meant for you onto someone else with Short range, including allies.
tooltip: You deflect an Intrusion meant for you onto someone else with Short range. Only usable once between Rests.

name: Weird Flex, But Okay
description: Some people just need to learn some humility. Whenever another character or creature critically succeeds at a task, you can call them out on their hubris, stealing their thunder in the process and causing them to fail instead, though without an Intrusion. You then critically succeed on the next task you take on.
tooltip: You succeed at a Task when another character or creature critically succeeds, causing them to fail without an Intrusion instead.

name: Overwhelmed
description: It's just too much. You try and you try, and they bad things happen, and you didn't mean bad things to happen, and now things are bad, and you just don't like it when things go bad! Whenever you get a mixed success on a roll, you fail the roll instead an get an Intrusion. If you get an Intrusion this way, there's a fifty percent chance that the Intrusion will work in your favour. In practice, this means the GM will roll 1d2 to determine whether it works in your favour or not. For example, if you get a mixed success while trying to punch someone, you fail and get an Intrusion. As luck would have it though, you stumble while bawling your eyes out, missing your punch but body slamming your target over a cliff and killing them instead.
tooltip: When you get a mixed success, you fail the roll instead and get an Intrusion. There's a chance that the Intrusion will work in your favour.

name: Just In Case
description: You start the game with a small, Inexpensive item that you use regularly to wipe your eyes and nose.
itemname: Tissue Paper Box or Handkerchief (of your choice)

name: Touch Starved
tooltip: If you go for more than an hour without giving someone affection, remove one die on all dice rolls unrelated to giving affection.

name: Warm, Fuzzy Feeling
tooltip: Immediately after showing someone affection, add a die to your next Task roll.

name: Bear Hug
description: Using an almost supernatural strength, you pull a character or creature into a tight hug, pinning them in place for one round, or as long as you maintain the hug. This ability grants Warm, Fuzzy Feeling and cancels Touch Starved.
tooltip: You pull a character or creature into a tight hug, pinning them in place for one round, or as long as you maintain the hug.

name: Careful, I'm a Hugger
description:
You've always loved people. Doesn't matter who they are, what they've done. People are just great. And you love showing that adoration through hugs and other forms of affection. So much so that if you go too long without showing affection, you become Touch Starved, losing a die on all dice rolls unrelated to showing affection until you do. But when you do get to show affection, well, that's the best feeling. Giving affection gives you a Warm, Fuzzy Feeling, adding a die to your dice roll on the next task you take.

Affection can be displayed to any target, ally or foe, willing or unwilling. The Bear Hug ability cancels Touch Starved and is not affected by it, and grants Warm, Fuzzy Feeling, though any Task roll relating to giving affection to someone would work in the same way. If you go without showing affection for one hour, you are afflicted with Touch Starved. Warm, Fuzzy Feeling lasts for an hour , but is spent on the first Task roll since gaining the status.
tooltip: An hour without showing affection, become Touch Starved. Gain a Warm, Fuzzy Feeling for an hour or until the next Task after giving affection.

name: Aaaa–!
description: Whenever you enter a new area, consume drink or food or inspect something closely, the GM may give you an Intrusion that you can't refuse. When this happens, roll 1d2. On a successful roll, you do not react, and nothing happens. On a failed roll, you react strongly, getting an Intrusion relevant to whatever it is you interacted with. For example, entering a dusty room will cause you to sneeze, or eating a treat with nuts in it will cause your throat to close up.
tooltip: When the GM gives you an Intrusion you can't refuse, roll 1d2. On a failed roll, get an Intrusion.

name: Everyone Makes Mistakes
description: Hey, bad stuff just happens. Not much you could do about it. Or at least, that's what you'd like to convince someone of. Whenever someone who can understands you gets a mixed success on a task roll, you can convince them it wasn't all that bad, negating any negative consequences. You can only use this ability once between each Rest, and it cannot be used on yourself.
tooltip: Whenever someone who can understands you gets a mixed success on a task roll, you can negate any negative consequences.

name: Sloppy Attack
description: You make an Attack against a target of choice, ignoring any kind of form or technique, adding a die to your dice pool for the Attack roll. You do not suffer any negative consequences when getting a mixed success on this roll.
tooltip: You make an Attack against a target. You do not suffer any negative consequences when getting a mixed success on this roll.

name: Everyone Makes Mistakes
description: Hey, bad stuff just happens. Not much you could do about it. Or at least, that's what you'd like to convince someone of. Whenever someone who can understands you gets a mixed success on a task roll, you can convince them it wasn't all that bad, negating any negative consequences. You can only use this ability once between each Rest, and it cannot be used on yourself.
tooltip: You negate the negative consequences of a mixed success for someone who can understand. You cannot use this ability on yourself.

name: Fail Faster
description: Everyone always says you learn more from failure than from success. You earn twice as much XP from Intrusions than normal, awarding yourself 2 XP and giving 2 XP away to others.
tooltip: You earn twice as much XP from Intrusions than normal, awarding yourself 2 XP and giving 2 XP away to others.

name: Everyone Makes Mistakes
description:
Hey, bad stuff just happens. Not much you could do about it. Or at least, that's what you'd like to convince someone of. Whenever someone who can understands you gets a mixed success on a task roll, you can convince them it wasn't all that bad, negating any negative consequences. You can only use this ability once between each Rest, and it cannot be used on yourself.

You can now use this ability when someone who understands you fails a roll. They still get an Intrusion, but you convince them to keep going and you help them succeed at what they were trying to accomplish, in addition to getting an Intrusion.
tooltip: You negate the negative consequences of a mixed success of a target who can understand you, or make them succeed on a failed roll, though they still get an Intrusion.

name: Can't Stop, Won't Stop
description: You're always on the go, ready to take on the next challenge. That means you don't really like to sleep, I mean what's the point of sleep anyways, who really needs to sleep? You are no longer able to Short or Long Rest. You can only Rest using this ability. Whenever you want to Rest, roll 1d6 to see how many rounds you are Resting. You can only Rest every 2 hours. Resting with this ability heals the same amount as a Short Rest, but resets cooldowns as if you had a Long Rest.
tooltip: You Rest for 1d6 rounds, healing as if you had a Short Rest, but resetting cooldowns as if you had a Long Rest.

name: If I Have To
description: Why are people so incompetent? I mean, if they need help, you guess you could at least try to something—as long as you don't have to deal with the consequences if they screw it up. Whenever you Help someone, you can choose to ignore any negative effects if the person fails or gets a mixed success on their roll.
tooltip: You Help someone, ignoring any negative effects if the person you Helped fails or gets a mixed success on their roll.

name: Yeah, No
description: If you are actively trying to undo what another character has done in the same round, add a die to your dice pool for the Task roll.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool if you are actively trying to undo what another character has done in the same round.

name: Performance Anxiety
description: It's not that you're bad at talking. You just don't like being put on the spot. Remove a die from your dice pool for social interactions if another character initiated conversation with you.
tooltip: Remove a die from your dice pool for social interactions if another character initiated conversation with you.

name: Disassociate
description: You can now Guard in all encounters, not just combat. In practice, this means you can avoid speaking with someone or engaging with a problem without any negative consequences.
tooltip: You can now Guard in all encounters, not just combat.

name: Born Ready
description: You've always been the best at what you do. It's not even a contest really. Choose one skill, any skill, in which you are trained and are proud to be skilled at.

name: Guilt
description:
You will carry your dishonor, your shame, your humiliation with you all your life. As much as you'd like to forget about it, it is a part of you. Choose one of the following to represent your shame:

  • A physical representation of your shame on your body
  • An Artifact you carry with you at all times by choice
  • A reputation you cannot shake off and that follows you everywhere

Regardless of how your shame is represented, your shame removes one die from your dice pool on any social interaction in which your shame is acknowledged.

name: Mark of Shame
description: A visible scar on your face, a cybernetic leg, or perhaps an arm sleeve tattoo. However your shame manifests itself, it is a permenant physical reminder of your shame and lets everyone know who you are. Remove a die from your dice pool for any social interaction in which your shame is acknowledged.
tooltip: Remove a die from your dice pool for any social interaction in which your shame is acknowledged.

name: Bad Reputation
description: People hear your name, and they know. They see your face, and they know. What you've seen, what you've done. Remove a die from your dice pool for any social interaction in which your shame is acknowledged.
tooltip: Remove a die from your dice pool for any social interaction in which your shame is acknowledged.

name: Heavy Burden
description:
No matter how hard you try, you can't seem to get rid of it. You carry with you, always within reach, always visible—a reminder of what you did, and letting everyone know who you are.

The Artifact can be anything you wish, but must be portable and it should almost always be visible. Remove a die from your dice pool while carrying the Artifact for any social interaction in which your shame is acknowledged. The Artifact has no inherit monetary value.
itemeffect: Remove a die from your dice pool while carrying the Artifact for any social interaction in which your shame is acknowledged.

name: Pray for Forgiveness
description: You pray to the source of your faith, asking for forgiveness for something you've done. You can use this ability out of turn immediately after recieving an Intrusion. If successful, you ignore the Intrusion, but still fail the roll, if applicable.
tooltip: Use this ability out of turn immediately after recieving an Intrusion. If successful, ignore the Intrusion, but still fail the roll.

name: Moral Code
description: You take your faith's teaching very seriously. Any deviation from its sacred principles is heresy. Strict adherance is rewarded. Whenever you perform an Action that goes against your faith's moral code, you receive Harm. If you perform an Action that directly upholds and promotes your faith's moral code, you Heal a small amount of Harm on yourself instead. Discuss with the GM if an Action is relevant to your faith's moral code.
tooltip: Receive Harm when you do something against your moral code. Heal yourself when you do something that upholds your moral code.

name: Woah...Awesome!
description: You are stunned for one round whenever you encounter something new that you've never experienced before.
tooltip: You are stunned for one round whenever you encounter something new that you've never experienced before.

name: Unbound Enthusiasm
description: The world is amazing! So many new things to try! You try yourself at a something, full of bravado, adding a die to your dice pool for the Task. You cannot get an Intrusion, but can still fail the roll. You also do not feel the negative effects of a mixed success. You cannot use this ability to perform the same Task twice in a row, but you can use it to perform different Tasks.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool for a Task, as long as you didn't just try the same Task. You do not get negative effects on a mixed success and cannot get an Intrusion if you fail.

name: The Divine's Hand
description: Using your connection to the Divine, you imbue your weapon with the Divine's light. For as long as you hold the weapon, add your Magic die to any attack you make in addition to other modifiers. The weapon remains enchanted until your next Rest, or until it leaves your hands.
tooltip: You imbue your weapon with the Divine's light, activating the Divine Weapon status.

name: Divine Weapon
tooltip: Your weapon is imbued with Divine light, adding your Magic die to any attack you make in addition to other modifiers.

name: Divine Protection
description: Whenever you're about to die, you can make a 2d Magic roll to avoid dying. Each time you attempt to save yourself with this Ability before your next Long Rest, remove a die from your dice pool for this Action. You can perform this Feat even if you already acted this round.
tooltip: You make a 2d Magic roll to avoid dying. Remove a die from your dice pool each time you perform this Feat before Long Resting.

name: Vindicator
description:
Divine Magic was barely understood before Terrans colonized Plumeth. Psi Magic has always been easier for Erelen and Aeyen to use, so that they rarely dabbled in Divine Magic. However, Terrans seem naturally attuned to Divine Magic, wielding it with an uncanny familiarity. The Divine religion was founded by Terrans in reverence to the power Divine Magic brings. Aeyen and Erelen were eventually able to learn how to use Divine Magic more effectively by emulating Terrans, though they are not necessarily a part of the associated religious organizations, and very few are Vindicators.

After the Megor invaded, there came a need for a new type of soldier—one which could fight on the battlefield, but could also wield the Divine as a weapon against invaders strong in Psi Magic. Hence Vindicators were born, made up of Divine Clerics with a martial background and Terran soldiers with an affinity for the Divine. The Champions of the Divine is an organization composed mainly of Vindicators who fight alongside non-Magic users on warfronts and in civilian arenas.

Whether you are an active member of the Champions of the Divine or use Divine Magic without adhering to any specific beliefs, you have a connection to the Divine that allows you to heal and cleanse your allies, as well as attack your targets with burning light. You also have a martial background, allowing you to fight both with magical and physical might. Divine Magic is particularly effective against Psi users, artificial lifeforms and cyborgs. You also have access to the specialization Focus:

  • Enforces the Divine's Will
  • Wields a Divine Aegis

name: Familiar
description:
You have an immaterial familiar that only you can see that follows you around wherever you go. Whether it is a spirit remnant, an elemental being or a manifestation of your Magic, you decide its shape and size, though it can be no larger than yourself. It can interact with the physical world in limited ways, but is mostly just there to help you with everyday Tasks. It cannot Attack or be Attacked.

You have a mental link with your familiar, so you can see everything it sees and direct its actions through thought. You do not need to spend an Action directing your familiar, as it acts on its own turn separate from you. However, you roll for your familiar. If you lose your familiar, you can reconnect with a new one with a week of continuous soul searching.
itemeffect: An immaterial familiar that only you can see that follows you around. It can interact with the physical world in limited ways, but is mostly just there to help you with everyday Tasks. It cannot Attack or be Attacked.

name: Common Abilities
description:
Your familiar can interact with the physical world in limited ways. Select one of the following abilities for your familiar:
  • Share Secrets
  • Skill Enhancement
  • Scout Ahead

name: Share Secrets
description: Your familiar floats around the head of whoever you are speaking to and funnels the surface level thoughts of the person back to you.
tooltip: Your familiar floats around the head of whoever you are speaking to and funnels the surface level thoughts of the person back to you.

name: Skill Enhancement
description: Your familiar helps you accomplish Tasks related to a specific skill of your choice. Select something related to the shape and form of your familiar.

name: Scout Ahead
description: You send your familiar ahead up to a short range away, even through walls. Your familiar will send back all information to you until you recall it to your position.
tooltip: You send your familiar ahead up to a short range away, even through walls. Your familiar will send back information to you.

name: Paranormal Activity
description: Your familiar can now interact with the physical realm, being able to move objects up to your weight and can now Attack targets. However, while it can be Attacked, only you can see your familiar. Your familiar uses your Magic dice to attack, but can only attack at Melee range.
tooltip: Your familiar can now move objects up to your weight and can Attack targets and be Attacked, but is still invisible to others.

name: Uncommon Abilities
description:
Your familiar can interact with the physical world in more insidious ways. Select one of the following abilities for your familiar:
  • Haunt
  • Banshee Shriek
  • Skill Enhancement

name: Haunt
description: Your familiar can attach itself to a living target, infecting it and causing Harm each round for 1d4+2 rounds, or until it is forced out by the target by being cured or cleansed.
tooltip: Your familiar attaches itself to a living target, infecting it for 1d4+2 rounds, or until it is forced out.

name: Banshee Shriek
description: Your familiar unleashes a blood-curdling scream, causing all targets within Short range to run in fear.
tooltip: Your familiar unleashes a blood-curdling scream, causing all targets within Short range to run in fear.

name: Skill Enhancement
description: Your familiar helps you accomplish Tasks related to a specific skill of your choice. Select something related to the shape and form of your familiar.

name: Ethereal Made Real
description: Your familiar is now visible to everyone, is able to move objects up to your weight, can Attack targets and can be Attacked. In other words, they are entirely corporeal. Your familiar uses your Magic die to attack, but can only attack at Melee range.
tooltip: Your familiar is now visible to everyone, is able to move objects up to your weight, can Attack targets and can be Attacked.

name: Going Ghost
description: Your familiar becomes ethereal until the end of the following round, during which time it can perform Actions as normal, but cannot be targeted directly or seen by the naked eye.
tooltip: Your familiar becomes ethereal until the end of the following round. It can perform Actions, but can't be targeted normally.

name: All Together Now
description: If your familiar sacrifices their Action during the round, you can roll at least two Magic dice when rolling for Magic. If you use this Ability, your familiar cannot take any Actions at all, not even to move.
tooltip: Your familiar sacrifices their Action so you can roll at least two Magic dice. Your familiar cannot take any Actions, not even to move.

name: Power Absolute
description: Your word is law. It shall not be defied. Add a die to your dice pool for any social interaction in which you are telling someone what to do. Ignore any negative consequences if you get a mixed success.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool when telling someone what to do, ignoring the negative consequences of a mixed success.

name: Risk Management
description:
You no longer roll dice to resolve encounters. Instead, you have to calculate the risk involved in tackling a Task whenever you take an Action. The closer your risk calculations are to reality determine whether you succeed or not. Before each Action you take, you have to spend time making a risk assessment. Your risk assessment formula is as follows:

Base Risk + Worst Case Outcome + Threat Level - Modifiers

Your Base Risk is always your Species and Type. If receiving assistance from another character, always use the highest risk factor for your Base Risk. So for example, if you're a Terran Citizen (Base Risk 1), but you are recieving help from a T'avian Outlaw (Base Risk 5), then your Base Risk is 5 instead of 1. Use the following table to determine Base Risk:

 AeyanErelanEwocheK'ohmaMegorT'avTerranUisiZaoHybrid
Citizen1125511134
Cybermancer5555555N/A55
Divine Cleric332N/AN/AN/A2N/AN/A3
Dragoon44N/AN/AN/AN/A3N/AN/A4
ElementalistN/AN/A2N/A4242N/A4
Explorer4434444544
Field Medic3323433343
KeeperN/A1N/AN/AN/AN/AN/AN/AN/A2
Outlaw5545555555
Priestess of Ay'drielN/A2N/AN/AN/AN/AN/AN/AN/A3
Ranger2344432244
Recondite443N/A5N/A5N/A55
Shadow Warrior3234543324
ShamanN/AN/AN/A232N/AN/AN/A2
Fighter3445553355
Tech Expert2224323254
Vindicator3N/A2N/AN/AN/A2N/AN/A3

Worst Case Outcome is calculated based on how much potential Harm you could receive if you fail the encounter. The number ranges from 0 to 8, with 0 being no Harm and 8 being death. Threat Level is calculated by subtracting the Tier of the opposing force in the encounter from your current Tier, plus 1. The number ranges from 1 to 6; it can be no lower than 1, so if your Tiers are equal, then the Threat Level is 1. The information required to determine the Threat Level and the Worst Case Outcome amount is not readily available to you. You must make your best guess based on information provided by the GM, or you can ask specific questions to the GM via Insight.

Once you have the risk assessed, you must substract any relevant Modifiers provided by Feats, Skills, Traits, Items or Artifacts, including any negative ones that may apply as per the standard ruleset. So for example, if you're looking to jump over a pit filled with spikes as a Tier 4 Terran Explorer who is skilled in jumping, has a movement ability that adds a die to our dice pool and a rope, you could conclude (correctly) that there is a risk factor of 12, based on the following example calculations:

  • Base Risk – +4 (Terran Explorer)
  • Worst Case Outcome – +8 (Death From Spikes)
  • Threat Level – +1 (Tier 5 Spike Pit)
  • Modifiers – -3 (Skill + Feat + Item)

Success for an encounter is determined by how close you are in matching the GM's calculation each time you assess the risk of an encounter, as follows:

  • Critical Success – Your number matched the GM's calculation exactly
  • Success – You overestimated by no more than 3 points
  • Mixed Success – You overestimated by more than 3 points, or your underestimated by no more than 3 points
  • Failure – You underestimated by more than 3 points
  • Nothing – You decide not to follow through with your intended Action after assessing the risk

The effects of each outcome remain the same as the standard ruleset. Failure gets you an Intrusion, a mixed success has negative consequences and a critical success provides an additional desirable effect. Since you do not have an exact number, you cannot gain Insight through risk calculation. Using the example above, calculating a risk factor of 12 would award you with a critical success. At the same time, guessing 10 would be a mixed success, 15 a regular success, and 5 would be considered a failure and you would get an Intrusion.
tooltip: You no longer roll dice to resolve encounters, instead spending time before each Action calculating the risk factor. The closer you are to reality determines your success.

name: Risk Factors
description: You spend some time analyzing a situation before taking your intended Action in the next round. As a part of your analysis, you may ask the GM one question which they must answer truthfully, though they cannot provide anything directly related to your risk calculations. For example, you can ask what Tier an opponnent is, or what the worst outcome would be for the encounter, but you cannot ask for the total risk factor is or for individual numbers in the GM's calculation. You automatically succeed in this Task, but you must follow up the next round with an Action that does not involve risk assessment.
tooltip: You analyze a situation, asking the GM one question which they must answer truthfully. You must follow up the next round with an Action based on your assessment.

name: Risk Management
description:
You no longer roll dice to resolve encounters. Instead, you have to calculate the risk involved in tackling a Task whenever you take an Action. The closer your risk calculations are to reality determine whether you succeed or not. Before each Action you take, you have to spend time making a risk assessment. Your risk assessment formula is as follows:

Base Risk + Worst Case Outcome + Threat Level - Modifiers

Your Base Risk is always your Species and Type. If receiving assistance from another character, always use the highest risk factor for your Base Risk. So for example, if you're a Terran Citizen (Base Risk 1), but you are recieving help from a T'avian Outlaw (Base Risk 5), then your Base Risk is 5 instead of 1. Use the following table to determine Base Risk:

 AeyanErelanEwocheK'ohmaMegorT'avTerranUisiZaoHybrid
Citizen1125511134
Cybermancer5555555N/A55
Divine Cleric332N/AN/AN/A2N/AN/A3
Dragoon44N/AN/AN/AN/A3N/AN/A4
ElementalistN/AN/A2N/A4242N/A4
Explorer4434444544
Field Medic3323433343
KeeperN/A1N/AN/AN/AN/AN/AN/AN/A2
Outlaw5545555555
Priestess of Ay'drielN/A2N/AN/AN/AN/AN/AN/AN/A3
Ranger2344432244
Recondite443N/A5N/A5N/A55
Shadow Warrior3234543324
ShamanN/AN/AN/A232N/AN/AN/A2
Fighter3445553355
Tech Expert2224323254
Vindicator3N/A2N/AN/AN/A2N/AN/A3

Worst Case Outcome is calculated based on how much potential Harm you could receive if you fail the encounter. The number ranges from 0 to 8, with 0 being no Harm and 8 being death. Threat Level is calculated by subtracting the Tier of the opposing force in the encounter from your current Tier, plus 1. The number ranges from 1 to 6; it can be no lower than 1, so if your Tiers are equal, then the Threat Level is 1. The information required to determine the Threat Level and the Worst Case Outcome amount is not readily available to you. You must make your best guess based on information provided by the GM, or you can ask specific questions to the GM via Insight.

Once you have the risk assessed, you must substract any relevant Modifiers provided by Feats, Skills, Traits, Items or Artifacts, including any negative ones that may apply as per the standard ruleset. So for example, if you're looking to jump over a pit filled with spikes as a Tier 4 Terran Explorer who is skilled in jumping, has a movement ability that adds a die to our dice pool and a rope, you could conclude (correctly) that there is a risk factor of 12, based on the following example calculations:

  • Base Risk – +4 (Terran Explorer)
  • Worst Case Outcome – +8 (Death From Spikes)
  • Threat Level – +1 (Tier 5 Spike Pit)
  • Modifiers – -3 (Skill + Feat + Item)

Success for an encounter is determined by how close you are in matching the GM's calculation each time you assess the risk of an encounter, as follows:

  • Critical Success – Your number matched the GM's calculation exactly
  • Success – You overestimated by no more than 5 points
  • Mixed Success – You overestimated by more than 5 points, or your underestimated by no more than 5 points
  • Failure – You underestimated by more than 5 points
  • Nothing – You decide not to follow through with your intended Action after assessing the risk

The effects of each outcome remain the same as the standard ruleset. Failure gets you an Intrusion, a mixed success has negative consequences and a critical success provides an additional desirable effect. Since you do not have an exact number, you cannot gain Insight through risk calculation. Using the example above, calculating a risk factor of 12 would award you with a critical success. At the same time, guessing 10 would be a mixed success, 15 a regular success, and 5 would be considered a failure and you would get an Intrusion.
tooltip: You no longer roll dice to resolve encounters, instead spending time before each Action calculating the risk factor. The closer you are to reality determines your success.

name: Margin for Error
description:
You now have a larger margin of error when determining risk factors. You must underestimate over or under 5 points in order to trigger success/fail states, as in the following:
  • Critical Success – Your number matched the GM's calculation exactly
  • Success – You overestimated by no more than 5 points
  • Mixed Success – You overestimated by more than 5 points, or your underestimated by no more than 5 points
  • Failure – You underestimated by more than 5 points
  • Nothing – You decide not to follow through with your intended Action after assessing the risk
tooltip: You must underestimate or overestimate 5 points in order to trigger success/fail states.

name: Third Party Liability
description: You can now offer risk assessment services to other player characters, resolving their encounters using your abilities instead of them rolling. When calculating risk for another player character, you use their Species and Type to determine the Base Risk, and their character sheet for modifiers. Perfoming this Feat is considered a successful Help Action; make sure you include the Help bonus in the calculation for the other player character.
tooltip: You help resolve another player character's encounters using your Abilities, using their attributes as a part of your calculations.

name: Risk Factors
description: You spend some time analyzing a situation before taking your intended Action in the next round. As a part of your analysis, you may ask the GM two questions which they must answer truthfully, though they cannot provide anything directly related to your risk calculations. For example, you can ask what Tier an opponnent is, or what the worst outcome would be for the encounter, but you cannot ask for the total risk factor is or for individual numbers in the GM's calculation. You automatically succeed in this Task, but you must follow up the next round with an Action that does not involve risk assessment.
tooltip: You analyze a situation, asking the GM two questions which they must answer truthfully. You must follow up the next round with an Action based on your assessment.

name: Advanced Macro Probability
description: You have become so adept at risk assessment that you can calculate the risks involved in taking an Action and then take that Action, all in one round. If you spend your first Action assessing the risk or using your Risk Factors Ability, you can follow up with another Action in the same round.
tooltip: You calculate the risks involved of taking an Action and then take that Action. You must spend your first Action assessing the risk.

name: I Knew It!
description: You just have a feeling things are going to go badly. If you use your Action to name the Action you will be taking in the following round, you will not suffer any negative consequences or an Intrusion if you get a mixed success or fail the roll. However, you do not get an additional effect if you critically succeed. Naming your next Action uses up your entire Action, though you can still move an Immediate distance. You cannot use a Feat as your next Action; this Ability counts as your Feat for both rounds.
tooltip: Name the Action you will be taking in the following round. You cannot suffer any negative consequences or get an Intrusion, but cannot critically succeed.

name: The High Road
description: You automatically succeed at Helping someone as long as the action they take is not combat related.
tooltip: You automatically succeed at Helping someone as long as the action they take is not combat related.

name: Master of Opportunities
description:
You have a knack for finding jobs and for brokering business dealings for yourself and those around you. Choose one of the following to help you navigate the hustle and bustle of the market:

  • Datapad
  • Agency Contact

name: Agency Contact
description: A person with a local agency who can connect you with just the right jobs, the best brokers or the right opportunities for you and your group.
itemeffect: A person with a local agency who can connect you with just the right jobs, the best brokers or the right opportunities for you and your group.

name: Big Break
description: You receive a piece of Insight related to your current quest if you're currently on one, or to your next quest if you're in between adventures. Usable only once per Rest.
tooltip: You receive a piece of Insight related to your current or your next quest.

name: Prone to Trantrums
description: It's. Not. Fair! Whenever you fail a roll, there is a 50% chance that instead of an Intrusion, you will lose control of your temper and Trantrum. In practice, this means the GM will roll 1d2 to determine whether it works in your favour or not. While in your tantrum, you attack targets at random—friend or foe—in melee range using your bare hands for three rounds, or until someone tries to stop you.
tooltip: There is a chance that you will Tantrum instead of getting an Intrusion when you fail a roll.

name: Tantrum
tooltip: After failing a roll, you attack friends and foes at random in melee range using your bare hands for up to three rounds.

name: Lost Bearings
description: Your sense of directions is frankly, well, awful. Whenever you get a mixed success on Task rolls related to movement or travel, you fail and get an Intrusion instead. However, whenever you get an Intrusion related to movement or travel, there's an equal chance that it works to your advantage. In practice, this means the GM will roll 1d2 to determine whether it works in your favour or not. Rather than hurting you, it helps, or it hurts your enemies. For example, you might discover you're charging many more enemies than you realized, but they are intimidated by you and run. You and the GM should work together to determine the details. The GM can also use Intrusions based on your nature normally (awarding XP) if they desires.
tooltip: When you get a mixed success related to movement or travel, you fail and get an Intrusion, though this may work to your advantage.

name: Drop Dead
description: Your beauty is enough to stun a target who can see you for one round.
tooltip: Your beauty is enough to stun a target who can see you for one round.

name: Glamour
description: Add a die to your dice pool for any social interaction, using your beauty to your advantage.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool for any social interaction, using your beauty to your advantage.

name: Kink
description: Maybe it's a bit weird, but you don't think people should judge. Everyone has a thing—yours just happens to be a bit outside the box. You have a very distinctive kink that governs your thoughts, and you are trained in one skill related to that kink.

name: That's Not Fair!
description: You can re-roll any roll whenever you feel the resolution is unfair without paying XP. Only usable once between Rests.
tooltip: You re-roll any roll whenever you feel the resolution is unfair without paying XP. Only usable once between Rests.

name: Resentment
description:
You'll remember that. Whenever you get an Intrusion, you can hold a Grudge. At any time, you can satisfy your Grudge to add a die to your dice pool on any Task roll. That'll show them.

You can only hold one Grudge at a time, and you no longer hold a Grudge after satisfying it by adding a die to your dice pool for a Task.
tooltip: Whenever you get an Intrusion, you can hold a Grudge. You can satisfy your Grudge to add a die to your dice pool on any Task roll.

name: Gaudy
description: You do something so absolutely filthy that all targets in Short range are stunned at your lack of restraint.
tooltip: You do something so absolutely filthy that all targets in Short range are stunned at your lack of restraint.

name: Grudge
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool for any Task roll, after which your Grudge is satisfied.

name: Not Me, Never Me
description: Whenever you so choose, you can Guard against the negative consequences of a mixed success or the harmful effects of an Intrusion out of turn. Only usable once between each Rest.
tooltip: You Guard against the negative consequences of a mixed success or an Intrusion. You can use this ability if you already acted this round.

name: Don't Try Try Again
description: You cannot perform the same Action when re-rolling, so you must perform an entirely different Action each time your re-roll. You also cannot perform the same Action two rounds in a row.
tooltip: You must perform an entirely different Action each time your re-roll and you cannot perform the same Action two rounds in a row.

name: Whatever
description: Yeah, you don't really care if you fail. You can ignore an Intrusion once between each Rest, though you still fail the roll. You can use this Feat even if you already acted this round.
tooltip: You ignore an Intrusion, though you still fail the roll. You can use this Feat even if you already acted this round.

name: Sightless
description: Whether due to a birth defect, an unfortunate accident or your own volition, you are effectively blind, being unable to percieve the world visually. You must instead rely on your other senses to interpret the world around you. As such, you automatically fail any Task that relies exclusively on sight. However, you can no longer have disadvantage on rolls involving sight or be afflicted by the Blind minor effect.
tooltip: You are effectively always blind, and as such, you automatically fail any Task that relies exclusively on sight.

name: Resource Reallocation
description:
You may not be able to see, but that doesn't mean you're helpless. Either through experience or context, you've learned to pay closer attention to your other senses. Alternatively, you have a Seeing Eye Guide to assist you. Select one of the following as your primary way of interacting with the world:

  • Echolocation
  • Good Vibrations
  • Seeing Eye Guide
  • The Nose Knows

name: Good Vibrations
description: You've always felt more connected to the world through your sense of touch. Whenever you truly want to know what something is made of, all you have to do is feel it. Your sense of touch is so sensitive that you can pick up on the tiniest of movements, and usually give a pretty accurate picture based on that alone. Add a die to your dice pool whenever you try to percieve something through your sense of touch or by feeling vibrations in physical objects.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool whenever you try to percieve something through your sense of touch or by feeling vibrations in physical objects.

name: Echolocation
description: They say that sound doesn't travel through space, but you know better. You've heard the cosmic noise coming form the universe as clearly as music coming from the next room, after all. What's more, you can pretty accurately describe things around you just by standing and listening. Add a die to your dice pool whenever you attempt to percieve the world through your sense of hearing.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool whenever you attempt to percieve the world through your sense of hearing.

name: The Nose Knows
description: No matter how much people may claim otherwise, everything has a smell. From sterile laboratories to junk yards, you've smelled it all and you can tell a ripe apple from a rotten one through scent alone. Add a die to your dice pool whenever you attempt to percieve the world through your sense of smell.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool whenever you attempt to percieve the world through your sense of smell.

name: Supplementary Aid
description: You provide assistance someone, using your distinct abilities to ensure they reach their goal. If you fail your Help roll, you can take another Action this round, though you cannot Help again.
tooltip: You Help someone, taking another Action this round if you fail, though you cannot Help again.

name: Sixth Sense
description: Your focus on mastering your disability has allowed you to tap into a hidden potential within yourself, manifesting itself as Aura Magic. Using your limited skill in Aura Magic, you are able to send out a pulse up to a short range around yourself, percieving the world around you as if seeing it, but with a deeper understanding than anyone with sight could see with their eyes alone. You may ask the GM one question about the area around you up to a short range away from you, which they must answer honestly.
tooltip: You send out a pulse of Aura Magic up to a short range away, asking the GM one question about the area which they must answer honestly.

name: Aura Magic
description: Whenever you use your Magical Abilities from your Focus, you are using your body's innate energy through Aura Magic. Aura Magic focuses on self-discovery, the strength of self and the ability to materialize inner strength for external use. Aura Magic is most often used to increase an individual's physical capabilities beyond their natural limits. Aura can also be manifested as an external force to push or pull in a given direction. All sentient beings have an aura, ch'i or spirit which can be sensed by those adept in Aura Magic. An individual's aura contains their essence and can be read, manipulated or destroyed.
tooltip: You can use Magic, and your Magical Abilities from your Focus use Aura Magic.

name: Leech Vitality
description: With a touch, you leech vitality from a target, restoring a small amount of your health. Each time you attempt to leech the same target, remove a die from your dice pool. Your dice pool returns to normal after you've had a Long Rest.
tooltip: With a touch, you leech vitality from a target, restoring a small amount of your health.

name: Blood Magic
description:
Whenever you use Magic, you are unleashing the nocous power of Blood Magic. A perversion of Psi Magic, proficiency in the use of Blood Magic is dependent on the knowledge of the individual and is limited by their constitution. Individuals can only use Blood Magic for so long before succumbing to fatigue or worse, and must restore their dimishing vitality by absorbing the essence of others.

Blood Magic is barely understood, as dangerous to the user as it is to their foes. If you already have Magic, Blood Magic acts as a supplement or perversion of your existing Magical Abilities.
tooltip: You have Magical Abilities tainted by Blood Magic.

name: Cold Hard Truth
description: You tell someone who can understand you something a truth so frank that they stand stupefied, unable to act for one round.
tooltip: You tell someone who can understand you something a truth so frank that they stand stupefied, unable to act for one round.

name: Unbothered
description: You know the price of being forthright with people and you're used to the eventual backlash. You do not get Intrusions from social interactions, though you can still fail rolls.
tooltip: You do not get Intrusions from social interactions, though you can still fail rolls.

name: Check This Out
description: You call the shot, then you take it. Add a die to your dice pool for any Task roll as long as you boast about it first. If you get a mixed success, you fail and get an Intrusion instead.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool for any Task roll as long as you boast about it, failing and getting an Intrusion if you get a mixed success.

name: Psychic Drain
description: By speaking to someone who can understand you, you slowly drain their energy, restoring a small amount of health. You can maintain this Ability for as long as you like each round, but you must wait until you've Rested to use it again once you stop speaking.
tooltip: You slowly drain the energy of a target who can understand you by speaking to them, restoring a small amount of health.

name: Time Moves Slow
description: You're used to doing nothing in your free time, so time tends to move pretty slowly for you. As a result, every moment in time stretches out, allowing you to take two Actions in the same round. Only usable once between each Rest.
tooltip: Every moment in time stretches out, allowing you to take two Actions in the same round. Only usable once between each Rest.

name: Paid No Heed
description: It doesn't take long for people to figure you out. After just a few moments of conversation, people tend to avoid conversations with you, making it more difficult for you to get your word in or to initiate conversation. Remove a die from your dice pool on social interactions with people you've already spoken to.
tooltip: Remove a die from your dice pool on social interactions with people you've already spoken to.

name: Drone
description: Ever since you were a child, you've always loved learning. And you know enough about one topic to endlessly divulge information and factoids on people during conversations. You are trained in one knowledge Skill of your choice, preferrably something that would bore people if they had to listen to you speak about it for too long.
itemname: Knowledge Skill (that you think bores people)

name: Do As I Say
description: You tell someone what to do, automatically adding a die to their dice pool if they follow your instructions. If they don't, you fail to Help, meaning you feel any negative consequences from a failed encounter for the person you were aiming to Help.
tooltip: You automatically add a die to someone's dice pool when Helping if they follow your instructions. If they don't, you fail to Help.

name: Crunch Time
description: You can go twice as long without Long Resting, so you can stay awake for 48 hours instead of the usual 24 before you feel any negative effects from sleep deprivation.
tooltip: You can go twice as long without Long Resting.

name: Always On the Move
description: You can Short Rest and take another Action in the same round. Once of your two Actions must be to Rest, but you can take your two Actions in any order. This Feat counts as an additional Short Rest and can only be used once between each Long Rest.
tooltip: You Short Rest and take another Action in the same round. You can take your two Actions in any order.

name: Gimme a Minute
description: You raise your hand or verbally ask for a timeout for one round to deal with something important, such as consulting your datapad or speak to another character. If successful, all enemies within short range who can understand you stop any attacks against you, though they can still take other Actions.
tooltip: You cause all enemies within short range who can understand you stop any attacks against you for one round.

name: Preoccupied
description: You have so much to do and so little time to do it. Paying attention to anything but your work is a lost cause. Remove a die from your dice pool whenever you are undertaking a Task that requires concentration, such as in-depth conversations or problem solving.
tooltip: Remove a die from your dice pool whenever you are undertaking a Task that requires concentration.

name: Somehow Endearing
description: Despite your best efforts, people stick around you like glue, finding your disposition inviting. Add a die to your dice pool for any social interaction, ignoring any negative consequences of a mixed success if you are not participating in a positive manner.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool for any social interaction, ignoring any negative consequences of a mixed success if you're being negative.

name: Hesitation
description: If you spend a round doing nothing while you think over the Action you're about to take, add two die to your dice pool for any Task roll.
tooltip: Add two die to your dice pool for any Task roll if you spend a round doing nothing while you think over the Action you're about to take.

name: Patch Up
description:
With your previous knowledge or using what tools you have available, you stabilize a wounded target. Stabilizing someone does not heal them; instead, you mitigate the negative effects from being damaged for 4 hours, or until their next Long Rest.

A stabilized character no longer removes a die from their dice pool while Unstable.
tooltip: You stabilize a wounded target, mitigating the negative effects from being damaged for 4 hours, or until their next Long Rest.

name: No One Left Behind
description: Taking care of people also means you sometimes have to support them—literally, physically support them. Pulling on hidden reserves of strength, you lift another character who cannot walk or move, supporting most of their weight as you move together. While carrying another character, you have limited movement, having to spend an entire Action to move an Immediate distance, or rolling to move a Short distance. You have at least one hand free, so you can still take Actions, as long as they don't involve athletics or the use of two hands. While being carried, your supported character is effectively prone, so they must spend an Action to get off you or to perform most physical Actions. Lasts until cancelled, by either you or the supported character.
tooltip: You lift another character who cannot walk or move, supporting most of their weight as you move together.

name: Easy Breezy
description: You were never someone to take things too seriously. Add a die to your dice pool for any non-combat Task roll, ignoring any negative consequences if you get a mixed success.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool for any non-combat Task roll, ignoring any negative consequences if you get a mixed success.

name: Broken Artifact
description: You don't quite remember how you came into the possession of the damn thing; all you know is that you broke it shortly after getting it, and now you can't seem to convince yourself to throw it away. You start the game with an Artifact decided on by the GM. You do not know what the Artifact did when functional.
itemeffect: An Artifact with an unknown function, largely due to the fact that it is broken.

name: Ready For Anything
description: You've prepared for every outcome, seen all possibilities. You're ready to face the world, safe with the knowledge you can't be hurt. You do not feel the negative effects from mixed successes. This means you only need one die to get a full success.
tooltip: You do not feel the negative effects from mixed successes.

name: What's Mine is Yours
description:
Everyone needs help. No matter who it is or what they've done in life, you feel compelled to help. This may be as simple as giving someone your money or your attention, but it could go as far as giving XP to another player character or going on an elaborate quest for someone. You aren't a mindless drone, however; you can refuse to help outright villains, or to fulfill favours that would make you do things that make you uncomfortable. But on the whole, you do what you can to help people. If you don't, the GM can give you an Intrusion that you can't refuse.

When you do help people, you receive a point of a resource unique to you: Karma. Karma is a representation of the good deeds you've done. You can spend a point of Karma once per round to:

  • Add a die to any dice roll.
  • Heal a point of Harm on yourself.
  • Gain 1 XP.
  • Re-roll a dice roll.
  • Gain Insight.

      • You can store as much Karma as you want, but you can only ever spend one Karma per round. You can Spend Karma and do another Action each round.
tooltip: You gain Karma when helping others, which you can spend for various benefits. The GM can give you Intrusions you can't refuse if you don't assist others.

name: Spend Karma
description: You spend a point of Karma, adding a die to any dice roll, healing a point of Harm on yourself, gaining 1 XP, re-rolling a dice roll or gaining Insight. You can perform this Action and another in the same round.
tooltip: You spend a point of Karma, adding a die to any dice roll, healing yourself, gaining 1 XP, re-rolling a dice roll or gaining Insight. You can perform this Action and another in the same round.

name: No
description: You force yourself to say no to someone who can understand you, avoiding any Intrusions that would normally result from doing so, but also stunning you for the round. Only usable once between each Rest.
tooltip: You say no to a target who can understand you, avoiding any Intrusions but also stunning you for the round.

name: Stream of Thoughts
description: Add a die to your dice pool for any social interaction.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool for any social interaction.

name: Resource Reallocation
description:
You may not be able to hear, but that doesn't mean you're helpless. Either through experience or context, you've learned to pay closer attention to your other senses. Alternartively, you have a USL Interpreter companion. Select one of the following as your primary way of interacting with the world:

  • Eagle Eye
  • Good Vibrations
  • The Nose Knows
  • USL Interpreter

name: Eagle Eye
description: Light sets the standard for speed in the universe. All things, all forces and rules of reality defer to light when it comes to speed. And without the normal distractions that would hinder you, you can tap into that great power to see further than any other. Add a die to your dice pool whenever you attempt to percieve the world through your sense of sight.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool whenever you attempt to percieve the world through your sense of sight.

name: Silence of the Void
description:
Whether due to a birth defect, an unfortunate accident or your own volition, you are effectively deaf, being unable to percieve the world through sound. You must instead rely on your other senses to interpret the world around you. As such, you automatically fail any Task that relies exclusively on hearing. However, you are no longer affected by Attacks or effects that rely on sound.

While you can vocalize, you are not able to really speak, so your preferred method of communication is through universal sign language. Your language skills only apply to the written word.
tooltip: You are effectively always deaf, and as such, you automatically fail any Task that relies exclusively on hearing.

name: Bindings Unchecked
description: You're used to silence, with only your own thoughts reverberating in your mind. But now...something else. Whispers at the back of your mind, invading your thoughts, telling you things. Things you shouldn't know, secrets and hidden truths. You may ask the GM one question about a target up to a short range away from you, which they must answer honestly.
tooltip: You ask the GM one question about a target a short range away which they must answer honestly.

name: Shadow Magic
description: Whenever you use Magical Abilities from your Focus, you are unleashing the ravenous nightmare that is Shadow Magic. If you already have Magical Abilities, they are tainted by Shadow Magic, but still use their Magic of origin. Shadow Magic is a powerful, yet dangerous Magic that drains its user as much as it does whomever the Magic is aimed at. A Magic of pure destruction, its manifestation alone is enough to erase reality around its nexus. Anyone who is found using Shadow Magic is normally consumed from within before long.
tooltip: You can use Magic, your Magical Abilities from your Focus use Shadow Magic, and your other Magical Abilities are tainted with it.

name: Speechless
description:
Whether due to a birth defect, an unfortunate accident or your own volition, you are effectively silenced, being unable to communicate through sound. You must instead interact with the world around you in more creative ways. As such, you automatically fail any Task that relies on verbal communication. However, you can no longer be prevented from using abilities or be afflicted by the Silenced minor effect.

As you are not able to speak, your preferred method of communication is through universal sign language. Your language skills only apply to the written word.
tooltip: You are effectively always silenced, and as such, you automatically fail any Task that relies exclusively on speech.

name: Physical Dexterity
description:
You may not be able to speak, but that doesn't mean you're helpless. You are trained in a dextirity skill afforded to you through your experience with communicating non-verbally, or you have a USL Interpreter companion. Select one of the following:

  • Finesse
  • Perception
  • Performance
  • Stealth
  • USL Interpreter

name: USL Interpreter
description:
You have a trusty, every-constant companion who follows you around, providing interpretation services between yourself and other characters you encounter. The interpreter can be a person, an android or something similar.

You do not control your interpreter's Actions. They act independently of you, has their own personality and free will, but will always provide interpretation services during conversations in which they are present. Discuss the particulars of your interpreter companion with the GM. If you lose your interpreter, you can get a new one within 1d6 days.
itemeffect: A universal sign language interpreter who follows you around and provides translations for yourself and other characters during conversations.

name: Seeing Eye Guide
description:
You have a trusty, every-constant companion who follows you around, guiding you safely through the world. The guide can be a person, an android, an animal or something similar.

You do not control your guide's Actions. They act independently of you, has their own personality and free will, but will always guide you through environments they can traverse. Discuss the particulars of your guide companion with the GM. If you lose your guide, you can get a new one within 1d6 days.
itemeffect: A seeing guide who follows you around, allowing you to navigate spaces safely.

name: Psi Magic
description:
Whenever you use Magic Abilities from your Focus, you are tapping into the unbound power of Psi. Proficiency in the use of Psi Magic is dependent on the knowledge of the individual and is limited by their constitution. Individuals can only use Psi Magic for so long before succumbing to fatigue or worse.

If you have other Magical Abilities, they do not necessarily use Psi Magic.
tooltip: Your Magical Abilities from your Focus use Psi Magic.

name: Telepathy
description: You've had an itch in the back of your mind for some time now. A feeling that if only you could connect to people, you could communicate with them directly. It's only now that the gates have opened, allowing you to speak telepathically with others, almost as if speaking aloud. Communication via telepathy with other people goes both ways, and they don't need to consent to you intruding their mind. You don't have to see the target of this Ability to use it, but you must know for a fact they are within long range.
tooltip: You speak telepathically with a target within long range, almost as if speaking aloud.

name: Walls Closing In
description: Remove a die from your dice pool whenever you are in a space that does not allow you to move a short distance in any direction, or is shorter than your height when standing.
tooltip: Remove a die from your dice pool whenever you are in a space that does not allow you to move a short distance in any direction, or is shorter than your height when standing.

name: Always at the Ready
description: You carry around with you a small kit with all the cleaning supplied needed to keep yourself and the world around you clean, including disinfectant wipes, sanitizer, shoe shiner and so on.

name: Spic & Span
description: If at any point your clothes or person become soiled, you must spend at least one round cleaning the offensive filth off yourself, being unable to take any other Action than clean and defend yourself for the duration. Time spent cleaning yourself is based on the source of the dirt and how successful you are at cleaning.
tooltip: You spend at least one round cleaning yourself, being unable to take any other Action than clean and defend yourself for the duration.

name: Meditate
description: You induce a meditative state, closing yourself off from the world, clearing your mind and healing your body. This Ability replaces both your Short and Long Rests. You can Meditate at any time, for any duration of time you want, but you must sleep at least eight hours to gain the benefits of a Long Rest.
tooltip: You induce a meditative state, clearing your mind and healing your body. This Ability replaces both your Short and Long Rests.

name: Centre Self
description:
Your efforts have paid off. You now have more mastery over your own mind than ever before. While you can't clear your mind completely for long periods of time, you can shut off certain parts of your mind indefinitely, allowing yourself to focus on certain aspects of yourself more effectively.

Whenever you use this Ability, activate either Free of Violence or Immediate Reflexes. Free of Violence pacifies you, but adds a die to any non-combat Task roll while active. Immediate Reflexes silences you, but adds a die to all combat Task roll while active. You can only have one or the other active at any point in time; activating one will disable the other. Activate either Free of Violence or Immediate Reflexes without rolling when you initially acquire this Ability.
tooltip: Close parts of your mind away, activating either Free of Violence or Immediate Reflexes. Only one can be active.

name: Free of Violence
tooltip: Add a die to any non-combat Task roll, but you are pacified while this Ability is active.

name: Immediate Reflexes
tooltip: Add a die to any combat Task roll, but you are silenced while this Ability is active.

name: <hide>
description: You are tethered to another character. Make note of that character here.

name: Like Glue
description: You just can't help yourself. Some would say you're even obsessed. But in your mind, you're just doing what you need to do to make sure you don't lose what's important to you. Whenever you wish, you can spend your Action to designate another character as the centre of your attention. You do not need to roll to designate someone. Add a die to all your dice rolls as long as you are within Immediate distance of that character. You can change who want to cling to as often as you want, but you can only cling to one character at a time.
tooltip: Add a die to your dice pool for any Task roll when in immediate distance of a character you designated as the centre of your attention.

name: Tip of the Iceberg
